Award.AwardTitle: New Perspectives on Nonlinear Waves: Taming Modulational Instability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The nonlinear Schr√∂dinger (NLS) equation is a fundamental model equation in modern mathematical physics. This equation may serve, for example, to describe both certain water waves and the propagation of light in optical fibers. However, the nonlinear nature of this equation is an obstacle that prevents the straightforward application of most existing general-purpose mathematical tools. This project will use the special structure of this equation to examine in detail two features of its solutions, called modulational instability (MI) and supercontinuum generation (SCG). While the starting point of these investigations is based on the mathematical properties of the NLS equation, MI and SCG are important phenomena in the real world. For example, MI has been proposed as an important element in the formation of "rogue waves" in the ocean; these rare but relatively large and spontaneous waves may be quite dangerous. Furthermore, SCG is important in optical telecommunications systems and in optical coherence tomography, an imaging technique used in opthalmology to reveal detailed retinal structures. A better understanding of this mathematical phenomenon thus has the potential to influence the design and development of telecommunications systems and optical devices.

This project's investigation of MI and SCG is based on the initial-value problem for the focusing NLS equation in the small-dispersion regime. In this regime, nonlinear effects are dominant, and solutions exhibit small-scale oscillations and violent transitions (nonlinear caustics) to even more complicated oscillatory patterns. Both MI and SCG figure prominently in this behavior. Indeed, in the limit of vanishing dispersion (also known as the semiclassical limit), MI suggests that a generic plane wave solution may be expected to break immediately into some other, presumably more disordered, form. However, recent results show that there do exist distinguished perturbations which do not excite the acute modulational instabilities known to be present in the small-dispersion regime. This project will incorporate such special perturbations into the broader theory of the zero-dispersion limit of the focusing NLS equation. As part of this effort, a scheme for classifying and describing these perturbations will be developed. Once this is done, the import of such special perturbations for applications can be assessed. Another component of this research will be to extend a non-standard method for computing the Fourier Power Spectrum of solutions to a broader class of initial data; once completed, this method will give a new, direct way to measure the impact of wave breaking (nonlinear caustics) on SCG.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nonlinearity arises generically in mathematical models of physical phenomena, and the NLS equation is one of the fundamental model equations in modern nonlinear mathematical physics. However, despite a tremendous recent advances, a complete understanding of its properties, especially in the semiclassical regime, remains a challenge in pure and applied mathematics.
For example, both modulational instability and supercontinuum generation have been proposed as key players in the formation of rogue waves, but such waves are not yet completely understood. The primary results of this project established certain relation between the eigenvalue value perturbations of the Zakharov-Shabat problem and the onset of modulational instability. For bell-shape initial conditions, certain perturbations, such as the one generated b Gaussian semiclassical soliton ensemble (SSE), all of the eigenvalue perturbations were unidirectional. This kind of perturbations does not trigger the modulational instability, as long as the perturbation decays at a rate with respect to the small parameter. However, for the similar perturbed bell-shape initial data generated by eigenvalue perturbation that decays at the same rate as that of the Gaussian SSE, but is not unidirectional, the perturbation triggers the modulational instability right away.  

Other outcomes of the project include the continuation method for tracking the trajectory of each individual eigenvalue on the parameter space. Based on the root following method of Humpherys and Lytle, we implement a method that allows us to follow the trajectory of each individual eigenvalue of the non-selfadjoint Zakharov-Shabat eigenvalue problem on the parameter space. This method, dubbed as the continuation method, reformulate the eigenvalue problem

on the real line into a two-point boundary value problem (BVP). For a small increment of the parameter, the previously computed eigenvalue is used as an initial guess for the two-point BVP. Our numerical experiments indicate that this method is more suitable than Bronski's shooting method or the Hill's method if we only wish to follow the trajectory of an individual eigenvalue on the parameter space.
